Burlington 12th September

Your last letter my beloved Brother was received on
tuesday and need I say that your high approbation and increased affection
more than repays me for any past privations and sufferings 
already [illegible] founded by the [illegible] of my Creator and ardent attachment
and almost painful gratitude exhibited by our departed Servant.
Of the Last hours of his existence I have wished [our savior?] that existence
[indeed? succeed?] to send you a particular account, but I have delayed doing
so because I hoped that in a short time I should be able to look back
for the event without that sensation of agony which at first accompanied
[introspection?] so painful but it is too recent yet to be recounted
without [many?] many tears and [John?] induced to undertake it now
because I will not permit a selfish feeling to deprive you of the melancholy
satisfaction of reading my statement. In my letter of the 8th
I informed you what an alarming change had taken place without
any apparent reason, The [illegible] which [illegible] him was violent and
long one. [Jane?] persuaded that Death had then stricken his victim I
essayed every art to restore warmth but without effect until I administered
a little Sprits of water as hot as it could be borned taken shortly
after this he fell asleep and slept as quietly for two hours. I watched by him
with all the anxiety of affection and awaited his awakening in the hope that
he would be better but alas it was far otherwise he started and [in my?]
incoherent wandering [expressions?] escaped him, in all of them how
tenderly he spoke of me. I ever shall remember I was deeply distressed

[Cross writing]
extinct at length that [pressure?] ceased the motionless hand was covered with the dew
of Death and the strained ear could no longer hear any symptoms of existence. Mrs
Fraser returned to the apartment but I spoke not, I moved not, I was [illegible] with
feelings I cannot describe on the lifeless lady before me, but I was roused by the accounts
of kindness which entreated me since it was all over to leave the room I
closed with my own hands those eyes which had so long looked on me with tenderness
and helped those [less?] which were wont to bless my down [nothing?] and my up rising.
The rest of this night passed alone and spent in thanking
my Creator for the mercies he had shewn me in enabling me to do my duty
even to that dreadful hour and in fervently acknowledging that since no prospect
of recovery remained it was a mercy to put an end to sufferings which augmented
day after day until even he who loved him almost wished for Death
to crow with the reward which can only be attained thro [through] this medium such
exemplary patience and Christian resignation. I have often heard persons say that
in the first moments of affection Religion could not exercise its power but for
myself I can truly say that I felt its sweet influence at the very moment I was
[readying?] my Parent and my Friend The next evening I visited the chamber of death
and took a last farewell of the remains of one so dearly loved. I knelt beside the
insensible body, remembered the lifeless form and hoped the day [could?] [delay?] I prayed
for Fortitude to sustain the trial yet in store for me and God has decorated me such
mercies as will be matter of rejoicing for ever. The following day I attended the  

[End page 1]

by the visible alteration which I observed but I said nothing and endeavoured
to relieve the sufferings I could not avert, as I sat beside him he exclaimed
help me and extended his hand I instantly raised him up and
was terrified at the gasping for breath which had thus suddenly [assayed?]
him, it was long ere the restoratives I offered procured any relief and I
administered them in an anguish of mind I cannot permit for every moment
threatened to put an end to existence at length respiration became
easy and he sunk into a state of almost torpor while this continued
he retained a perfect consciousness of every thing and in accents [handy?]
and [able?] offered up a prayer to that God in whom he trusted, Sleep
did not visit his eyes that night and on the following morning the alteration 
became [illegible] more perceptible Sunday was passed in much
suffering and I cannot describe to you what I suffered for in addition
to the certainty of soon losing my beloved Parent was the misery of beholding
his agonies without the power of relief indeed of increasing them
for I could not move him without inflicting pain, I was so much occupied
by him that I did not go to Prayers at the usual time he reminded
me of it and begged me to unite with him in asking that
support and mercy which we both needed as much, I did so and when
I had finished went to the bed he threw his arm around me as I
leaned over him and drawing me to him helped me and blessed me then fervently
entreated God to bless his Child and reward her for her goodness
to him. He will bless me my dear Father I said for the prayers of the
righteous are the sweetest kindness that can be offered to him. The night
and day following he suffered much very much but not a murmur not
a groan escaped him his [reorgination?] and his patience seemed perfected
 
[Cross writing]
funeral the service now performed in [illegible] manner then it is in
our churches a part of it was read and then as discourse delivered after which
the [illegible] appoints the rest of it was read at the grave, thither I went and
beheld all that was easily consigned to its native dust, and I sorrow not as one without
Life But trust that if I finish my promising faith I shall meet my [departed?]
Present In Heaven- [Adieu?] my dearest Brother Remember
me affectionately to all the family and Tell mama to use no painful effort to
write to me I am indebted to Sally and the Girls and will write soon but
my eyes are sometimes quite painful-
Yr Affy [Yours Affectionately] S.M.G [Sarah M. Grimke]

[End page 2]

and Petitions for mercy and Fortitude wer incessantly mingled with
Thanksgivings and Praise. Towards evening he said to be How merciful
is God who with so much suffering and such long and severe trials
has given me strength to bear them and filled me for the mansions of
bliss by with drawing every earthly enjoyment and teaching me to love
him above all things, I feel satisfied that when I pass there the dark
valley of the shadow of death his rod and his staff will comfort me
I am sinking he continued very fast but let this [aforesaid?] console you.
I could not reply emotions prevented utterance, I continued to sit beside
him and administer a beverage to quench the thirst which consumed
him, an application of Laudanum had relieved his pain [illegible]
I had placed every thing comfortable, I took my seat beside [illegible]
looked at me [illegible] and said you must not fatigue yourself by watching
I replyed that I could not leave him at least until he slept, a faint
smile illumined his face for a moment as he fervently said. Oh God
how sweet to sleep and wake no more, his last prayer was uttered but
a few minutes ere it was answered, he put one of his hands round my
neck as I bent down and with the other pressed mine, his pillow was supported
on my lap, and he seemed then satisfied; at his request the candle was taken 
from the room and shed uncertain and gloomy light through the
apartment from the passage, but I wanted not light to tell me that
the awful hour of dissolution was near, Mrs Fraser had left the room
and alone at the hour of midnight I watched the fatal indication of
approaching Death, my eyes were freed or that face whose heavenly
calmness seemed to say I sent in peace, a gentle pressure of my hand
and an almost imperceptible respiration alone proved that life was not 

[End page 3]

[To:] Thos. [Thomas] S. Grimke Esq.
Charleston
So Ca [South Carolina]

[Note]
S.M. Grimke
10 Sep 1819
Account of our
Father's death.

[First line illegible]
is nothing else and no book. No provisions have been made for winter
clothed at Belmont.- It was our intention when we went to Mr. y.-
to purchase some trifle as presents to the family, Do you think I am at
liberty now to lay out any money in that way. My Father was very liberal
to me and constantly [illegible] me to purchase every thing I wanted and I shall
regret it if those for whom he destined his gifts do not get them. I believe
after paying a visit here I shall go back to Mrs. F. as she seems
